  PROJECT AT A GLANCE 

 
 

 

 

   

INTRODUCTION 

 
1. 
The  transaction  involves  the  administration  of  an  equity  investment  of  up  to  the  Indian 
rupee equivalent of $2,000,000 to be provided by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Ventures 
Investment  Fund  1  in  Smart  Joules  Private  Limited  (SJPL)  in  India. 1  Consistent  with  the 
establishment arrangements for the fund, ADB will not invest its own capital alongside the fund.2   
 
2. 
SJPL is an India-based provider of data-driven energy efficiency solutions for commercial 
buildings,  targeting  large  hospitals  as  the  beachhead  market.  SJPL  delivers  energy  savings 
through a combination of (i) a proprietary Internet of Things (IoT)-based sensing and analytics 
platform, and (ii) the application of an Energy Efficiency as a Service (EEaaS) business model. 
The  investment  will  improve  energy  efficiency  in  commercial  buildings  by  reducing  carbon 
emissions and making the distribution system smarter. SJPL’s vision to promote energy efficiency 
and  eliminate  energy  poverty  aligns  with  ADB’s operational  priorities  to tackle  climate  change, 
building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability in Asia and 
the Pacific. 3,  
 

 

THE INVESTMENT 

 

Investment Identification and Description 

 
3. 
Indian  energy  sector.  India  is  the  world’s  third  largest  electricity  consumer.  Energy 
demand grew by about 6% annually during 2010–2019, in line with growth in India’s population 
and average income levels. India’s energy-related carbon dioxide emissions comprised 6.4% of 
the  global  share  in  2019.  Energy  demand  could  double  by  2040,  with  electricity  demand 
potentially  tripling  because  of  increased  appliance  ownership  and  cooling  needs.  Without 
significant improvements in energy efficiency, India will need to add massive amounts of power 
generation capacity, of which about 60% is coal-fired.4 
 
4. 
Energy efficiency industry overview. India’s energy saving potential is estimated to be 
15%–30% across all demand segments, totaling about $10 billion per annum, with commercial 
and  industrial  buildings  offering  very  high  saving  potential. 5 Cooling  services  are  particularly 
energy-intensive in the  commercial  and  industry building  segment,  with  India’s  air-conditioning 
market expected to increase more than 30 times to 1 billion units by 2050.6 The energy efficiency 
industry in India, however, faces various financial and technical barriers that deter investment. 
Financial  barriers  include  the  weak  balance  sheet  of  traditional  energy  efficiency  service 
providers,  the  small  size  and  high  transaction  costs  of  individual  projects,  and  high  risk 
perceptions of financial institutions because of limited familiarity and capacity to evaluate energy 
efficiency service providers. 
 
Women’s participation in the energy efficiency solutions industry. The energy sector 
5. 
is  a  nontraditional  area  for  women  because  of  the  stereotypical  view  of  energy  technological

unaddressed.10   
 
6. 
Energy service company industry. Despite public sector interventions, including ADB 
projects,  India’s  energy  service  company  (ESCO)  industry  has  faced  market  development 
challenges.11  ESCOs have typically struggled to scale up because of the lack of transparency in 
actual savings, lack of clear ownership rights between tenant and building owners to apportion 
the  resultant  energy  savings,  uncertain  payback  periods,  and  the  consequential  inability  to 
generate appropriate financial returns on investments made by the ESCOs. Technology (including 
the  use  of  IoT,  sensors,  and  artificial  intelligence  data  analytics)  and  innovative  financing  are, 
however, creating a new generation of EEaaS and equipment as service providers in emerging 
markets. These new technology-enabled business models are generating more significant energy 
savings and faster payback periods.12

THE ADB ASSISTANCE 

The Assistance 

 
7. 
ADB  will  administer  the  provision  of  assistance  by  the  fund  of  up  to  the  Indian  rupee 
equivalent of $2,000,000 by way of an equity investment in SJPL. The investment will be in the 
form  of  new  equity  (through  a  fresh  issuance  of  shares),  and  ADB  is  expected  to  have  an 
ownership  stake  of  about  10%.  ADB  will  have  the  right  to  nominate  a  member  or  observer  to 
SJPL’s  board  of  directors.  ADB’s  investment  will  constitute  about  50%  of  this financing  round. 
ADB expects to mobilize parallel equity financing of at least $8 million during 2021–2024. ADB is 
expected  to  provide  active  support  to  help  strengthen  governance,  incorporate  measures  to 
directly address gender equality in SJPL’s business activities to narrow gender disparities, and

8. 
Reporting arrangements. ADB will monitor the investment, and investment reporting will 
be subject to certain information disclosure requirements, in addition to  compliance with Indian 
legal and regulatory requirements. SJPL will provide ADB with financial reports at predetermined 
regular intervals and on request, including (i) a report on the use of the subscription proceeds, 
(ii) quarterly  and  annual  financial  statements  for  the  past  period,  and  (iii)  annual  budget  and 
business plans for the following financial year.

Evaluation. Monitoring reports will be prepared and submitted to ADB at least annually. 

9. 
The first report will be submitted no later than 12 months after the first disbursement. 
 

 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

 
10. 
Support the development of Energy Efficiency as a Service. Asia and the Pacific is 
expected to double its energy consumption by 2030, so the role of ADB in implementing energy 
projects  is  more  crucial  than  ever.  The  investment  will  support  the  evolving  field  of  energy 
efficiency, which is critical in reducing India’s carbon footprint and in addressing climate change. 
By leveraging ADB’s network, SJPL will be catalytic in establishing EEaaS as a business model. 
Further, the fund’s long investment horizon will allow SJPL to leapfrog into other emerging Asia 
markets—limiting divestment concerns. 
 
11. 
Resource  mobilization.  The  investment  is  anticipated  to  have  a  significant  signaling 
effect and is likely to increase the market’s confidence in SJPL achieving its business goals. This 
will help SJPL in critical areas, such as testing new products, and attracting future debt and equity.  

12. 
Progress  to  market-leading  standards.  As  the  first  and  only  development  finance 
institution shareholder, ADB will help develop and support SJPL’s adherence to high corporate 
governance  and  integrity  standards,  as  well  as  its  adoption  of  market-leading  social  and 
environmental standards, with potential demonstration effects in the Indian energy sector. ADB 
will also add value to SJPL by assisting it to (i) establish a more balanced board, including the 
creation  of  a  financial  management  committee  and  an  audit  committee;  (ii)  implement  an 
environmental and social management system; and (iii) incorporate gender-inclusive workplace 
policies.

further help address issues of sexual harassment in the workplace, which are prevalent in India.

DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

 
The  investment  is  aligned  with  the  Government  of  India’s  mission. 15  The  expected 
14. 
outcome  of  the  investment  is  to  reduce  the  electricity  consumption  of  commercial  buildings  in 
India.16 The  expected  outputs  of  the  investment  are  increased  capacity  of  SJPL  to  implement 
revenue-generating energy efficiency projects and enhanced gender equality in the workplace.  
 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

 
15. 
Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The investment is in all respects 
compliant with the fund’s objectives, as set out in the relevant contractual documents. In addition, 
the  investment  will  contribute  to  the  following  operational  priorities  of  Strategy  2030  and  the 
corresponding operational plans (OP): (i) addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities 
(OP1);  (ii)  accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality  (OP  2);  and  (iii)  tackling  climate  change, 
building  climate,  disaster  resilience  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability  (OP3). 17 The 
investment  is  also  aligned  with  the  objective  of  the  India  country  partnership  strategy  of 
addressing climate change and increasing climate resilience.18  
 

 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions

Statement  (2009)  as  follows:  environment  (category  C),  involuntary  resettlement  (category  C), 
and indigenous peoples (category C).19

ADB has undertaken due diligence and reviewed the potential environmental and social 
17. 
impacts of the investment. The business operations and SJPL’s plan for the use of ADB proceeds 
will not cause any significant adverse effects to the environment and will not trigger involuntary 
resettlement or indigenous people safeguards.  
 
18. 
SJPL  has  demonstrated  compliance with the  applicable  national  laws,  regulations,  and 
standards covering environmental management, labor and social protection requirements. The 
investment is expected to increase economic opportunities by creating 250 new jobs, and SJPL 
commits to adhere to applicable labor laws and internationally recognized core labor standards. 
Such compliance will be reported to ADB annually. The Summary Poverty Reduction and Social 
Strategy is available in the list of linked documents in Appendix 2. 

 

Gender  equality.  This  investment  is  classified  effective gender mainstreaming.  SJPL’s 
19. 
corporate policies have several provisions that support women employees—notably the “Striving 
for Greater Diversity in Team Smart Joules” initiative, which directly promotes women’s welfare 
and aims to increase the share of female employees from the 9% ratio in technical roles and in 
overall staffing. In its mission to build general skills on energy efficiency solutions, SJPL is looking 
to  further  promote  more  women’s  participation.  Following  ADB’s  Policy  on  Gender  and 
Development (1998), SJPL has incorporated measures to promote gender equality and women’s 
empowerment in its business activities. Key gender actions relate to targeting the participation of 
clients’ female staff in capacity building activities on the use of energy efficiency solutions, and 
enhancing gender equality at the company level through the implementation of a women-focused 
recruitment  strategy  and  an  internship  program  focused  on  female  students  or  graduates  in 
technical  fields.  A  gender  target  was  also  identified  to  raise  awareness  among  Smart  Joules’ 
employees on this issue, with the introduction of training for staff on sexual harassment  in the 
workplace. SJPL will submit periodic reports on implementation of gender measures to ADB. The 
Gender Action Plan is available in the list of linked documents in Appendix 2. 
 

 

Anticorruption Policy 

 
20. 
SJPL was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 

 

Assurances 

 
Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),20 
21. 
ADB  will  proceed  with  the  assistance  upon  establishing  that  the  Government  of  India  has  no 
objection  to the  assistance  to  SJPL.  ADB  will  enter  into  suitable  investment  documentation,  in 
form and substance satisfactory to ADB. 
 

 

THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 

 
The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
22. 
administration of an equity investment of up to the Indian rupee equivalent of $2,000,000 in Smart 
Joules  Private  Limited  in  India,  to  be  provided  by  the  ADB  Ventures  Investment  Fund  1,  and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
